metadata.titleEn: Qilian Mountains integrated observatory network: Dataset of Heihe integrated observatory network (Phenology camera observation data set of Sidaoqiao superstation-2019)
metadata.description:
The dataset contains the phenological camera observation data of the Sidaoqiao Superstation in the downstream of Heihe integrated observatory network from August 28,2019 to December 31, 2019. The instrument was developed and data processed by Beijing Normal University. The phenomenon camera integrates data acquisition and data transmission functions. The camera captures data by look-downward with a resolution of 1280×720. For the calculation of the greenness index and phenology, the relative greenness index (GCC, Green Chromatic Coordinate, calculated by GCC=G/(R+G+B)) needs to be calculated according to the region of interest, then the invalid value filling and filtering smoothing are performed, and finally the key phenological parameters are determined according to the growth curve fitting, such as the growth season start date, Peak, growth season end, etc. For coverage, first, select images with less intense illumination, then divide the image into vegetation and soil, calculate the proportion of vegetation pixels in each image in the calculation area. After the time series data is extracted, the original coverage data is smoothed and filtered according to the time window specified by the user, and the filtered result is the final time series coverage. This data set includes relative greenness index (Gcc).
Please refer to Liu et al. (2018) for sites information in the Citation section.

background: Arid and semiarid regions represent approximately 30 % of the global terrestrial surface area (Dregne, 1991; Scanlon et al., 2006), and dryland expansion occurs under climate change, especially in developing countries (Huang et al., 2016). An oasis is a unique ecological landscape in arid and semi-arid areas that is not only the core of regions’ ecological environment but also the foundation of their economic development, especially in western China, which has been an important part of the “Silk Road” since ancient times. Oases comprising less than 10 % of the total area of arid regions support more than 90 % of the population in these regions of China (Chu et al., 2005; Li et al., 2016; Zhou et al., 2022). The oasis–desert system plays a crucial role in maintaining a stable ecological environment and agricultural productivity (Zhang and Zhao, 2015). Extensive studies have investigated energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas based on field and remote-sensing observations (Taha et al., 1991; Potchter et al., 2008; Xue et al., 2019; Wang et al., 2019; Zhou et al., 2022) and numerical simulations (Chu et al., 2005; Meng et al., 2009; Georgescu et al., 2011; Liu et al., 2020). In addition, oasis–desert areas located in semiarid regions have been found to be carbon sinks by previous researchers (Tagesson et al., 2016; Wang et al., 2019); thus, they can significantly affect the carbon balance of arid regions and play an increasingly important role within the global carbon cycle.
research objective: Therefore, it is critical to maintain the balance between oasis and desert systems in order to achieve the goal of sustainable oasis development. Understanding the basic characteristics of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems is important to achieve the goals of carbon peaking and carbon neutrality in the oasis–desert area and support the ecological security and sustainable development of the oasis. A quantitative understanding of the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas is crucial to recognize the oasis–desert interactions and is significant to protect the ecological stability and socioeconomic development of oases; moreover, long-term observations are indispensable.
challenges: Inland river basins in arid and semiarid areas are facing the crisis of ecological environment degradation, such as the drying up of rivers and lakes, the degradation of natural vegetation, the intensification of land desertification, and the frequent occurrence of dust storms, especially in many inland river basins westward along the Silk Road, such as the Tarim River basin (Zhao et al., 2013), the Aral Sea basin (Stanev et al., 2004; Crétaux et al., 2009), and the Lake Urmia basin (Stone, 2015).
methods: In this study, we present a suite of observational datasets from artificial and natural oasis–desert systems that consist of long-term energy, water vapor, carbon and methane fluxes as well as auxiliary data involving hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters from 2012 to 2021. Half-hourly turbulent flux data were acquired by an eddy covariance system and scintillometer. The hydrometeorological data (including radiation, soil heat flux, and soil temperature profiles; gradients of air temperature and humidity and of wind speed and direction; and air pressure, precipitation, and soil moisture profiles) were observed from automatic weather stations with a 10 min average period as well as the groundwater table data. Moreover, vegetation and soil parameters were also supplemented in the datasets. The data processing and quality control procedure can be divided into data collection, data processing, and data archiving and sharing.
dataset: The study area comprises the middle and lower reaches of the HRB, located in the arid regions of western China, that receive water from the typical cryosphere of the upper reaches. A total of 11 land surface flux and meteorological stations have been established in these regions since 2012 – 2 superstations and 9 ordinary stations. The dataset of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange observations in oasis–desert areas reported in this study (including energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes; hydrometeorological data; and vegetation and soil parameters) is freely available from the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center.

Definition.Question: What does 'phenocam observation data' refer to in the context of surface process observation networks?
Definition.Answer: Phenocam observation data refers to data collected using phenocams, which are cameras designed to monitor vegetation phenology. In the context of surface process observation networks, these cameras capture images that are used to calculate indices like the Green Chromatic Coordinate (GCC), which helps determine key phenological parameters such as the start, peak, and end of the growing season.

Definition.Question: What is meant by 'relative greenness index' in vegetation monitoring, and how is it calculated?
Definition.Answer: The 'relative greenness index' in vegetation monitoring is a measurement used to quantify vegetation greenness based on image data. It is calculated using the Green Chromatic Coordinate (GCC) formula: GCC = G / (R + G + B), where R, G, and B are the red, green, and blue pixel values of the image. This index helps in identifying phenological events by analyzing changes in greenness over time.

Definition.Question: How is 'canopy cover' determined in phenocam observation datasets?
Definition.Answer: Canopy cover in phenocam observation datasets is determined by first preprocessing images to select those taken under optimal lighting conditions. The images are then segmented into vegetation and soil components. The proportion of vegetation pixels within the area of interest is calculated to estimate canopy cover. This data is further processed and filtered over a specified time window to produce a smooth time series of canopy cover values.

Comparison.Question: How do the data collection methods for phenological camera observations compare to those used for energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange measurements in oasis-desert systems?
Comparison.Answer: Phenological camera observations involve vertical, downward-facing cameras to collect high-resolution images, which are then processed to calculate greenness indices and vegetation cover. In contrast, energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange measurements rely on eddy covariance systems and scintillometers for flux data, and automatic weather stations for hydrometeorological data.

Comparison.Question: In terms of data processing and quality control, how does the approach for handling phenological camera data compare to that for energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange data?
Comparison.Answer: Phenological camera data processing focuses on calculating greenness indices, filling missing values, and smoothing time series data for vegetation cover analysis. On the other hand, energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange data require comprehensive quality control procedures, including data collection, processing, archiving, and sharing, ensuring the reliability of long-term flux and meteorological data.

Interpretation.Question: How can the integration of phenology camera data and eddy covariance measurements enhance our understanding of energy and water vapor exchanges in oasis–desert systems?
Interpretation.Answer: The integration of phenology camera data with eddy covariance measurements allows for a comprehensive analysis of the interactions between vegetation dynamics and energy and water vapor exchanges. Phenology cameras capture vegetation changes over time, which, when combined with eddy covariance data that provide half-hourly energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes, can offer insights into how vegetation phenology influences ecosystem exchange processes. This combined approach supports a quantitative understanding of oasis–desert interactions, important for ecological stability and sustainable development.

Interpretation.Question: What challenges arise in maintaining long-term observation datasets for energy, water vapor, and carbon exchanges in arid regions, and how can these be mitigated?
Interpretation.Answer: Challenges in maintaining long-term observation datasets in arid regions include ecological environment degradation, such as river and lake drying, vegetation degradation, and intensified desertification. These are compounded by logistical difficulties in remote areas. Mitigation can involve establishing a network of observation stations, using automated data collection systems for continuous data acquisition, and ensuring robust data processing, quality control, and archiving protocols. Long-term datasets are indispensable for understanding oasis–desert interactions and addressing ecological security.

Interpretation.Question: What methodologies can be employed to ensure the quality and reliability of data collected from meteorological stations in harsh desert environments?
Interpretation.Answer: Methodologies to ensure data quality and reliability include using automatic weather stations equipped with sensors for radiation, soil heat flux, temperature and humidity gradients, wind speed and direction, and other parameters. Regular maintenance and calibration of equipment are crucial, along with implementing rigorous data processing and quality control procedures. Data archiving and sharing protocols help in validating and verifying the collected data, ensuring its reliability for long-term ecological and climate studies.

Causal Consequence.Answer: Challenges like drying up of rivers and land desertification may necessitate the use of more robust and diverse data collection methods, such as combining remote sensing with ground-based observations, to effectively monitor and address ecological degradation in inland river basins.

Causal Consequence.Answer: Long-term observation datasets can provide crucial insights into the carbon exchange dynamics in arid regions, supporting the development of strategies to achieve carbon neutrality by enhancing understanding of carbon sinks and sources in oasis-desert systems.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to maintain a balance between oasis and desert systems through data collection on energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Maintaining this balance is essential for achieving sustainable development of oases, supporting ecological security, and ensuring socioeconomic stability in arid regions. Understanding these exchanges helps in recognizing oasis-desert interactions and contributes to global carbon cycle assessments.

Goal Orientation.Question: What objectives are pursued by collecting long-term observational data from artificial and natural oasis–desert systems?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The objective is to gain a quantitative understanding of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchanges in these ecosystems. This can aid in addressing ecological degradation challenges, inform carbon peaking and neutrality goals, and support the resilience and productivity of oasis environments in arid regions.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How can phenology cameras be utilized to collect data on vegetation cover and growth phases in arid regions, and what are the key procedural steps involved?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Phenology cameras can be utilized by integrating data acquisition and transmission functionalities. The cameras are set up to capture images in a vertical downward direction with a resolution of 1280*720, at specified time intervals. Key procedural steps include calculating the relative greenness index (GCC) using the formula GCC=G/(R+G+B), where R, G, and B are pixel values from the image’s red, green, and blue channels, respectively. Invalid values are filled, and the data is smoothed through filtering. Growth curve fitting is then used to determine key phenological parameters such as the start of the growing season, peak, and end of the growing season. For vegetation cover, images are pre-processed by selecting those taken under moderate lighting conditions, segmented into vegetation and soil, and the vegetation pixel ratio is calculated. This data is then smoothed using a user-defined time window to create a time series of cover data.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the methodological steps involved in capturing and processing hydrometeorological data to support ecological and socioeconomic studies in oasis-desert ecosystems?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The methodological steps for capturing hydrometeorological data include setting up automatic weather stations to record variables such as radiation, soil heat flux, soil temperature profiles, gradients of air temperature and humidity, wind speed and direction, air pressure, precipitation, and soil moisture profiles. The data is averaged over a 10-minute period. Groundwater table data is also collected. Data processing involves quality control, data archiving, and sharing. This comprehensive dataset supports ecological and socioeconomic studies by providing a quantitative understanding of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchanges in oasis-desert ecosystems.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures are followed to establish and maintain long-term observational datasets in artificial and natural oasis-desert systems, and what types of data are typically included?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The procedures to establish and maintain long-term observational datasets involve setting up a network of land surface flux and meteorological stations that continuously monitor and record data. The data collection includes observations of energy, water vapor, carbon, and methane fluxes, as well as auxiliary data such as hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters. The stations, including superstations and ordinary stations, have been operating since 2012, capturing half-hourly turbulent flux data using an eddy covariance system and scintillometer. The dataset is then processed, archived, and shared, typically through platforms such as the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center.

Enablement.Answer: The collection of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange data in arid and semiarid regions is enabled by the use of eddy covariance systems and scintillometers for half-hourly turbulent flux data. Additionally, automatic weather stations equipped with sensors for radiation, soil heat flux, soil temperature profiles, air temperature and humidity gradients, wind speed and direction, air pressure, precipitation, and soil moisture profiles are used.

These datasets support the ecological stability and socioeconomic development of oases by providing a quantitative understanding of these exchanges, which is vital for maintaining the balance between oasis and desert systems.

Enablement.Answer: Accurate phenological observations using a phenocam require conditions such as appropriate lighting to ensure quality images, with data collected using a camera that captures images at a resolution of 1280x720. The method involves using a vertically oriented phenocam to capture images, processing these images to calculate the relative greenness index (GCC), and applying filtering and smoothing techniques to determine key phenological parameters, such as the start and end of the growing season.
